Crash Address:

  bssl::ssl_negotiate_alpn
  bssl::ssl3_select_parameters
  bssl::ssl3_accept
  
Sanitizer: undefined (UBSAN)

Recommended Security Severity: Medium

Regressed: https://oss-fuzz.com/revisions?job=libfuzzer_ubsan_boringssl&range=201707190509:201707200503

Issue filed automatically.

See https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/blob/master/docs/reproducing.md for more information.

This bug is subject to a 90 day disclosure deadline. If 90 days elapse
without an upstream patch, then the bug report will automatically
become visible to the public.

When you fix this bug, please
  * mention the fix revision(s).
  * state whether the bug was a short-lived regression or an old bug in any stable releases.
  * add any other useful information.
This information can help downstream consumers.

If you have questions for the OSS-Fuzz team, please file an issue at https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/issues.

This is pretty uninteresting/false-alarm, though I can fiddle with it a bit to try to shut this up. It's because our public headers need to be C-compatible, but, for safety security, we are slowly moving the library to C++. This means we need to play slightly iffy games where our internal translation units see slightly different typedefs.

One possibility is to go back to the "ssl_st subclasses bssl::SSLConnection" idea and hope it doesn't emit any symbols to pollute the namespace. I'll see if I can get that working.

I'm also surprised this hasn't flagged previously on stack.h. That library is made entirely of function pointer casts, though I have vague plans to fix it. Perhaps UBSan special-cases T* to void* parameter decay within a function pointer since everyone does it.
https://boringssl-review.googlesource.com/c/18224 should hopefully silence this false positive.

ClusterFuzz has detected this issue as fixed in range 201707200503:201707210505.
